content.raw: Just an idea: maybe the Apply Force/Torque option should be disabled for static models, since applying force or torque to them doesn't do anything...
content.html: Just an idea: maybe the Apply Force/Torque option should be disabled for static models, since applying force or torque to them doesn't do anything...

content.raw: Yes, that's on the todo list, I actually started implementing something, but I think it turned out to be difficult to find out if the model is static from the scene, so when right-clicking the model we'd have to query the server before running the `ModelRightMenu`. It was getting too complicated so I left it as future work. But it certainly should be revisited...
content.html: Yes, that's on the todo list, I actually started implementing something, but I think it turned out to be difficult to find out if the model is static from the scene, so when right-clicking the model we'd have to query the server before running the ModelRightMenu. It was getting too complicated so I left it as future work. But it certainly should be revisited...

content.html: ah, that makes sense. Yeah, that can be future work for the next PR.

content.raw: I saw a crash when I was trying to rotate Robonaut while the force/torque purple rotation axes were visible. I was trying to reproduce it with the Youbot, but instead I got in a weird state where both the XYZ rotate and force/torque GUI axes were visible. The model was moving at this point because I was rotating it. Normally when you rotate a model, it stops moving while you are dragging the axes. In this state, I could click and drag the Force/torque axes and cause the model to stop moving, like the behavior of the rotation axes.
content.html: I saw a crash when I was trying to rotate Robonaut while the force/torque purple rotation axes were visible. I was trying to reproduce it with the Youbot, but instead I got in a weird state where both the XYZ rotate and force/torque GUI axes were visible. The model was moving at this point because I was rotating it. Normally when you rotate a model, it stops moving while you are dragging the axes. In this state, I could click and drag the Force/torque axes and cause the model to stop moving, like the behavior of the rotation axes.

Jumping issue fixed 1eb7170

The previously focused spin was triggering mode change when the window is activated, so now focus is cleared before activating it.

Jumping issue fixed 1eb7170

content.raw:
This is how to reproduce both axes appearing (it's very subtle):

Open the force/torque dialog for a model.

Go into rotate mode so that the RGB axes of rotate mode appear. (works for translate and scale mode too)

Hover over the "Mag" box in the Force/Torque dialog and spin the mouse wheel. (I think it works for the other number boxes too.) This will increment/decrement the value inside and highlight the purple force/torque axes, but it won't hide the rotate/scale/translate axes.

![forcetorqueaxes.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4185341457-forcetorqueaxes.jpg)
content.html:
This is how to reproduce both axes appearing (it's very subtle):

Open the force/torque dialog for a model.

Go into rotate mode so that the RGB axes of rotate mode appear. (works for translate and scale mode too)

Hover over the "Mag" box in the Force/Torque dialog and spin the mouse wheel. (I think it works for the other number boxes too.) This will increment/decrement the value inside and highlight the purple force/torque axes, but it won't hide the rotate/scale/translate axes.

content.html: Ha! Thanks for reproducing this! Rotation and apply force should never be visible at the same time because they share the same logic. I'll look into it.

content.raw: It looks like if you apply force/torque when simulation is paused, then unpause, the applied forces queue up and affect the model all at once. You warn us not to pause simulation in the tutorial, but maybe you can warn the user what the pausing behavior is (unless you plan on changing this behavior).
content.html: It looks like if you apply force/torque when simulation is paused, then unpause, the applied forces queue up and affect the model all at once. You warn us not to pause simulation in the tutorial, but maybe you can warn the user what the pausing behavior is (unless you plan on changing this behavior).

content.raw: Optimize-y tip for the functions of `ApplyWrenchDialog`: Input parameters that are unchanged in the function should be declared `const`. Non-primitive types should be declared `const` reference (`const std::string &_modelName`, `const Vector3 &_force`, etc).
content.html: Optimize-y tip for the functions of ApplyWrenchDialog: Input parameters that are unchanged in the function should be declared const. Non-primitive types should be declared const reference (const std::string &_modelName, const Vector3 &_force, etc).

content.raw: I'm not sure what you mean. The torque visual needs a 90 degrees rotation about the Y axis to have the "donut" properly oriented with respect to the target link.
content.html: I'm not sure what you mean. The torque visual needs a 90 degrees rotation about the Y axis to have the "donut" properly oriented with respect to the target link.

content.raw: oh sorry, I was confusing the `GetQuaternionFromVector` function with the Quaternion constructor. There is a `gazeb::math::Quaternion(roll, pitch, yaw)` constructor that you could use here if you feel like it.
content.html: oh sorry, I was confusing the GetQuaternionFromVector function with the Quaternion constructor. There is a gazeb::math::Quaternion(roll, pitch, yaw) constructor that you could use here if you feel like it.

content.raw:
So, first I transform the direction vector into a rotation using `GetQuaternionFromVector` (I actually thought about adding this to the Quaternion class as a `Quaternion::LookAt` function for example).

Then I apply this rotation to the visual. But since the visual was not created properly oriented (maybe it should have huh), every time we need to rotate an extra PI/2 about Y. That's why I multiply `quat` by the other quaternion, which is created using the RPY constructor you mentioned.
content.html:
So, first I transform the direction vector into a rotation using GetQuaternionFromVector (I actually thought about adding this to the Quaternion class as a Quaternion::LookAt function for example).

Then I apply this rotation to the visual. But since the visual was not created properly oriented (maybe it should have huh), every time we need to rotate an extra PI/2 about Y. That's why I multiply quat by the other quaternion, which is created using the RPY constructor you mentioned.

content.raw:
very interesting... I traced back to the implementation of the crashing function, `lockImpl`, in the [Ogre source code](https://bitbucket.org/sinbad/ogre/src/edccf8cc52e3b23c5ce0a3c4d15d64c0c67ad6e0/RenderSystems/GL/src/OgreGLHardwareVertexBuffer.cpp?at=v1-8#cl-63) to get an insight for a fix. The only workaround I could think of possibly get is to check if `Ogre::HardwareBufferManager` (an Ogre singleton class) is NULL before the line that causes the segfault in `DynamicLines`. It appears to be the only pointer that goes unchecked in the function.

`GLHardwareBufferManager* glBufManager = static_cast<GLHardwareBufferManager*>(HardwareBufferManager::getSingletonPtr());`
content.html:
very interesting... I traced back to the implementation of the crashing function, lockImpl, in the Ogre source code to get an insight for a fix. The only workaround I could think of possibly get is to check if Ogre::HardwareBufferManager (an Ogre singleton class) is NULL before the line that causes the segfault in DynamicLines. It appears to be the only pointer that goes unchecked in the function.

GLHardwareBufferManager* glBufManager = static_cast<GLHardwareBufferManager*>(HardwareBufferManager::getSingletonPtr());

content.raw: Anyway, it sounds like the issue probably isn't caused by the Force/Torque GUI. It's either a general rendering library problem or an Ogre problem.
content.html: Anyway, it sounds like the issue probably isn't caused by the Force/Torque GUI. It's either a general rendering library problem or an Ogre problem.

content.raw: The pink circles for rotating the application point disappear if you move the mouse outside the Gazebo window. Then, they appear again only if you hover over the "Apply Force and Torque" window. Is this on purpose?
content.html: The pink circles for rotating the application point disappear if you move the mouse outside the Gazebo window. Then, they appear again only if you hover over the "Apply Force and Torque" window. Is this on purpose?

content.raw: This is intentional. You can have many Apply F/T dialogs open at the same time and several orange arrows visible at the same time, but the pink circles are attached only to those corresponding to the active dialog.
content.html: This is intentional. You can have many Apply F/T dialogs open at the same time and several orange arrows visible at the same time, but the pink circles are attached only to those corresponding to the active dialog.

content.raw:
I've rearranged the mutexes on 9f04246

# For `AplyWrenchDialog`:

`SetForce` and `SetTorque` change several variables, and they can be called either from the dialog (spins being edited, buttons being pressed) or when the mouse drags the pink rings. Apparently, if it was only the dialog callbacks it would be fine because all Qt callbacks are called sequentially. But since it also involves a gazebo `MouseEventHandler`, there might be more than one thread involved.

# For `ApplyWrenchVisual`:

Every function that modifies `forceVisual` and `torqueVisual` is being locked. Except for `UpdateForceVisual` and `UpdateTorqueVisual`, because these functions can be called from `SetMode`, which is locked. Instead, calls to `Update[F/T]` are locked inside `SetForcePos` and `SetCoM`.
content.html:
I've rearranged the mutexes on 9f04246

For AplyWrenchDialog:

SetForce and SetTorque change several variables, and they can be called either from the dialog (spins being edited, buttons being pressed) or when the mouse drags the pink rings. Apparently, if it was only the dialog callbacks it would be fine because all Qt callbacks are called sequentially. But since it also involves a gazebo MouseEventHandler, there might be more than one thread involved.

For ApplyWrenchVisual:

Every function that modifies forceVisual and torqueVisual is being locked. Except for UpdateForceVisual and UpdateTorqueVisual, because these functions can be called from SetMode, which is locked. Instead, calls to Update[F/T] are locked inside SetForcePos and SetCoM.

I didn't get a backtrace when I crashed earlier, but this might explain why I saw a crash when I first started the dialog.

content.raw: I added a mutex and I'm still able to reproduce this specific crash when using the scroll wheel to change links very fast.
content.html: I added a mutex and I'm still able to reproduce this specific crash when using the scroll wheel to change links very fast.

content.raw: D:
Just in case, mutex added anyways. I think it's a good idea even if it doesn't fix this specific issue c3ec44b
content.html: Just in case, mutex added anyways. I think it's a good idea even if it doesn't fix this specific issue c3ec44b

content.raw:
Talking with @chapulina, it shouldn't be problematic because this callback is triggered when there's a new response to a request. The request is fired when the user changes the link in the window dialog. So, it's unlikely that the user could select two links so fast that the response arrives almost at the same time.

That being said, I would use a mutex just in case something funky happens in the background and the transport sends the request twice for example. It's also nice that your code works no matter what happens in the outside.
content.html:
Talking with @chapulina, it shouldn't be problematic because this callback is triggered when there's a new response to a request. The request is fired when the user changes the link in the window dialog. So, it's unlikely that the user could select two links so fast that the response arrives almost at the same time.

That being said, I would use a mutex just in case something funky happens in the background and the transport sends the request twice for example. It's also nice that your code works no matter what happens in the outside.
